Package com.github.tommyettinger.cringe

Class ColorSupport

java.lang.Object
com.github.tommyettinger.cringe.ColorSupport
public final class ColorSupport extends Object
Color handling code that is used internally to implement some methods in GdxRandom, but can also be used by user code.

  • Method Details

    • hsl2rgb

      public static com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color hsl2rgb(com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color color, float h, float s, float l, float a)
      Converts the four HSLA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to the RGBA values in color, modifying color in-place. YES, IT MODIFIES THE GIVEN COLOR, SO DON'T PASS THIS A COLOR CONSTANT. I brought this over from colorful-gdx's FloatColors class. I can't recall where I got the original HSL(A) code from, but there's a strong chance it was written by cypherdare/cyphercove for their color space comparison. The h parameter for hue can be lower than 0.0 or higher than 1.0 because the hue "wraps around;" only the fractional part of h is used. The other parameters must be between 0.0 and 1.0 (inclusive) to make sense. Note that this takes a hue (h) as a value from 0.0 to 1.0, not an angle in degrees.
      Parameters:
      color - a non-null Color that will be modified in-place
      h - hue, usually from 0.0 to 1.0, but only the fractional part is used
      s - saturation, from 0.0 to 1.0
      l - lightness, from 0.0 to 1.0
      a - alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
      Returns:
      color, after changes

    • hue

      public static float hue(float r, float g, float b, float a)
      Gets the hue of the given RGBA color, from 0.0f to 1.0f, both inclusive.
      Parameters:
      r - red, from 0.0 to 1.0
      g - green, from 0.0 to 1.0
      b - blue, from 0.0 to 1.0
      a - alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (ignored)
      Returns:
      the hue as a float from 0 to 1, both inclusive

    • hsb2rgb

      public static com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color hsb2rgb(com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color color, float h, float s, float b, float a)
      Converts the four HSBA or HSVA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to the RGBA values in color, modifying color in-place. YES, IT MODIFIES THE GIVEN COLOR, SO DON'T PASS THIS A COLOR CONSTANT. I brought this over from colorful-gdx's FloatColors class. I can't recall where I got the original HSB(A) code from, but there's a strong chance it was written by cypherdare/cyphercove for their color space comparison. The h parameter for hue can be lower than 0.0 or higher than 1.0 because the hue "wraps around;" only the fractional part of h is used. The other parameters must be between 0.0 and 1.0 (inclusive) to make sense. Note that this takes a hue (h) as a value from 0.0 to 1.0, not an angle in degrees. HSB and HSV are synonyms, but it makes more sense to call the parameter "brightness."
      Parameters:
      color - a non-null Color that will be modified in-place
      h - hue, usually from 0.0 to 1.0, but only the fractional part is used
      s - saturation, from 0.0 to 1.0
      b - brightness or value, from 0.0 to 1.0
      a - alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
      Returns:
      color, after changes
